Articles.Content:
The alternative title to this post is: "Critical tools that the game never tells you about."

2 days ago I was thinking about all of the cool things I *could* do... if only I could somehow use SAS to lock my ship's orientation to vertical. Coincidentally, I then saw a video on Reddit of someone doing a "suicide burn" and saw him switch to the Radial Out on the navball in surface mode, and used it exactly the way I imagined it should be used, and once it clicked for me, it's like the whole game opened up in a new way. Now I can maneuver precisely like I never could before, and things that seemed impossible or too challenging to do repeatedly can become routine. Such as... grounded docking. (as an aside, I had before some moderate success with using robotics for grounded docking, but that success was short lived as I quickly learned that robot parts are packed with napalm and kraken bait)

Behold - Station "Yellowstone" on the surface of Mun!

The first part to hit the ground was the module to the rear in these images, with the ISRU and passenger cabins. I posted about that in the daily update thread a few days ago. Yesterday I added the science module and docked the two halves on the surface of the Mun. The science unit was launched with the same strategy as the power unit, except this one was assembled in kerbin orbit and flew itself to Munar orbit where it needed to be refueled, since it was significantly heavier. The little vehicle that is parked on top has every science experiment except crew report (didn't want to fit a crew module onto it) and four science storage units, it can hop to any biome on the Mun and collect four of every experiment, one for each of the MPLs. It was Supposed to be shipped in the cargo bay of the MPL module, however, the decoupler got stuck and it refused to disconnect, so there is still a full lander inside the cargo bay that has been de-activated permanently, and I had to send another one up to land itself.

The station is entirely gas-powered. There are a total of 8 fuel cell arrays (7 in the original body, 1 came with the science bays to pay for their own power). There is a single solar panel attached that was applied retroactively (thank you 1.11!!) since apparently the game doesn't consider fuel cell arrays as "power sources" for the purpose of fulfilling contracts. 

The surface docking, both horizontal and vertical, would not have been possible for me had I not known about the Surface Radial Out option. The general idea is that by locking your ship vertical and manipulating the throttle so that TWR is approximately 1, you can then maneuver the ship with RCS in the same way that you would in zero gravity. In execution it's a little more difficult, since not only are you more time limited since you are constantly spending gas, but also the fact that TWR fluctuates as you do.

I captured videos of the process of docking the two modules together and landing the science jumper. They are not edited and there's a lot of bad piloting but I figured I'd show what it looked like for anyone interested. I learned a lot from doing these, like for instance, reach a safe altitude before doing any extreme maneuvering of station-sized craft.

Here is the practice run at KSP where I was trying to do the vertical docking for the first time. I figured if I could do it on Kerbin then I would easily be able to do it on the Mun. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yNb2d-8WqNk

Here is the docking of the two halves of the outpost on the surface. I accidentally pointed the "rear end" (relative to the control point that I was using) at the target so I spent a lot of time confusing myself since my RCS controls were backwards. You will notice that I'm driving the power module to meet with the science module, I didn't feel as comfortable piloting the science module with precision since it was less balanced. The target docking port was on the downhill side, this is important for getting the two ports to actually touch for the final push, which was done by feathering the throttle up and pushing forward with full RCS. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e78Wl7ZWA5E

And here is the docking of the science jumper on the Mun. Lot of time wasted with over corrections (and a quick google search on the second screen to find out how to move the nav ball), but I will get better over time. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LHW6xbUHnpY

If anyone has any feedback or questions I will be happy to discuss! Thanks for reading!

 

 

Edited December 22, 2020 by quazarz
